title: Compressed romans used for Alcohol % and volume info on these French wine labels?
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819im_/http:/typophile.com/files/krug_680.jpg)  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819im_/http:/typophile.com/files/lanson_680.jpg)  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Bertand-Delespierre_BrutTrad_680.jpg)  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819im_/http:/typophile.com/files/champagne_moet_rose-680.jpg)

Hello Typophile

If any of you knowledgable folk can identify the typefaces used for the alcohol percentage and volume on the wine labels uploaded in this post I would be awfully grateful. I particularly love the one used on the Krug label, as it has the lightest footprint. Any suggestions for compressed romans with a more charigraphic nature rather than transitional/modern which would be suitable for the alcohol percentage and volume would be greatly appreciated.

Robert

Font: 

 Times, Garamond 3, New Century Schoolbook, Diotima 

Solved By: 

 [R.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/typophile.com/user/57325 "View user profile.")

| --- | --- |

author: Robert Elliott

comments.content: Moët & Chandon is [squooshed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/typophile.com/node/33713) [Times](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/linotype/times_pro_complete_vp/ot_ps?&fg=000000&bg=ffffff&sample_size=50&sample_text=ALC.%2012%25%20BY%20VOL.&ft=liga). Bertrand-Delespierre is some squooshed Century, maybe [Century Schoolbook](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/new_century_schoolbook_std_roman_adobe/opentype_cff/?&fg=000000&bg=ffffff&sample_size=55&sample_text=12%25%20Vol.%20750%20ml&ft=liga&acs_pt=32). Lanson is some heavily squooshed Garamond, maybe [Garamond No. 3](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/garamond_3_std_lt_std/opentype_cff/?&fg=000000&bg=ffffff&sample_size=65&sample_text=75%20cl%2012%2C5%25%20vol.&ft=liga&acs_pt=32). Krug is even more heavily squooshed [Diotima](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419021819/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/diotima_std_roman/opentype_cff/?&fg=000000&bg=ffffff&sample_size=60&sample_text=75%20cl%2012%2C5%25%20vol.&ft=liga&acs_pt=32).
R.: Thank you -- you nailed it. Very impressive. It seems I need practicing on identifying fonts once squooshed. See above screenshot.

Kudos Robert for your effective comparison presentation. Worth emulating.  
Don
